_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Ben E Keith Executive Summary
One covered process located at 2300 North Lakeside Street Amarillo, TX 76107 
Ammonia Refrigeration System containing approximately 22,775# of Anhydrous Ammonia Refrigerant Grade. (99.98% pure or better).  Ammonia will be introduced on August 24th, 2006 and the process brought online on August 25th, 2006.  System will be run by the contractor till pull down period is over on September 28th, 2006.  
Facility adheres to OSHA 29CFR 1910.119 Process Safety Management.  It also has an emergency action plan based on 1910.38.  
Full response team including training per 1910.120, PPE, and a site plan has been formed with two teams of four responders per shift.  Local response agencies including the fire department and hospitals have been contacted and information has been relayed as to the hazards of the process and necessary treatments and responses.  The Fire Department has been given tours of the facility for each shift and shown the emergency features and invited to partake in Mock Drills.  We also went over our hazmat flag system with them which gives them not only directional information but wind speeds.  
We based our worst case and alternate worst case on the EPA dispersion charts.   
Our worst case encompasses 1 prison only which operates a similar facility utilizing the same chemicals.  They have been notified of our chemical inventory and our worst case scenario.
IIAR is the International Institute of Ammonia Refrigeration and is the leader in defining the rules and regulations to which the industry abides by.  This facility meets all IIAR requirements.
This facility was tested to the maximum working pressures and signed off on by the city inspector.  The system then was tested by use of vacuum and held for 1 week.  Once ammonia is inserted, testing with sulphur sticks will occur.  
The system was built to current codes and fully monitored and characterized within the facility and around the major leak points using electrochemical se

nsors and a control system that will isolate zones with in the system should a leak occur.  We added a new technology to aid in prevention of overpressurization called a crossover system.  It utilizes a pressure switch and solenoid to move refrigerant in the system from the high side to the low side.  We also have our relief valves with rupture discs.  This should minimize the release of ammonia from the system and prevent a catastrophic release.  This system and the locations of vessels inside a separate area should mitigate the release and allow the ammonia to escape through the ventilation system in the roof and outside at a height of 40'.  Ammonia rises in atmospheric conditions causing no ammonia to be located at ground level except within the sealed building.  

All technology is new and fully tested and state of the art.
All SOP's were written and trained by a third party RETA CIRO and CARO operator for ammonia refrigeration and revised and review by the operators of Ben E. Keith.
